title: This was the idea in Fortenbaugh
where he sees the Arist. Rhet. 1.2 and 2.1 as complementary

prefers to see them as distinct, referring to different settings. The fact that Aristotle deals very briefly with persuasion through character as opposed to his account on emotions (2.2−2.11) is attributed to the familiarity of the audience with this kind of argumentation, since it held its roots in Homer. This lack of originality, as opposed to Aristotle’s new, cognitive analysis of emotions, led him to restrict the length of the former and expand that of the latter
This strategy was very risky as to its results, as will be shown in due course, especially when dealing with experienced audiences like the Athenians
